definition:
Given a vector space $V$, the special linear group
${{\operatorname{SL}}}(V)$ is defined to be the subgroup of the general
linear group $\operatorname{GL}(V)$ consisting of all invertible linear
transformations $T: V \longrightarrow V$ in $\operatorname{GL}(V)$ that
have determinant 1.

If $V = \mathbb{F}^n$ for some field $\mathbb{F}$, then the group
${{\operatorname{SL}}}(V)$ is often denoted
${{\operatorname{SL}}}(n,\mathbb{F})$ or
${{\operatorname{SL}}}_n(\mathbb{F})$, and if one identifies each linear
transformation with its matrix with respect to the standard basis, then
${{\operatorname{SL}}}(n,\mathbb{F})$ consists of all $n \times n$
matrices with entries in $\mathbb{F}$ that have determinant 1.
